content: The "Veteran Access to Care Act of 2014" allows Department of Veterans Affairs patients with extended waiting times for appointments to receive hospital care and medical services at non-Department of Veterans Affairs facilities. The "Veteran Access to Care Act of 2014" authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to contract with non-Department facilities to provide hospital care and medical services to eligible veterans who have waited longer than the VA's wait-time goals. The "Veteran Access to Care Act of 2014" allows eligible veterans to receive hospital care and medical services from non-Department facilities if they face long wait times, are notified of unavailability, or live more than 40 miles from a VA facility. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure follow-up care for veterans who elect to receive services outside the Department. The "Veteran Access to Care Act of 2014" allows eligible veterans to receive hospital care and medical services at non-Department facilities. The Secretary must ensure that veterans receive necessary care at these facilities for up to 60 days. A quarterly report on care provided outside the Department must be submitted to Congress. The "Veteran Access to Care Act of 2014" allows eligible veterans to receive care at non-Department facilities. The Secretary must ensure veterans receive necessary care for up to 60 days and submit quarterly reports to Congress. The Act also outlines the purchase methods for care at non-Department facilities and defines key terms. The implementation of this section begins on the date of the Act's enactment. The authority of the Secretary to authorize payment for care at non-Department facilities terminates after 2 years from the enactment of the Act, except for ongoing care within a 60-day episode of care initiated before the end of the 2-year period. SEC. 3. EXPANDED ACCESS TO HOSPITAL CARE AND MEDICAL SERVICES. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must reimburse non-Department facilities for providing hospital care or medical services to covered veterans if access cannot be provided within wait-time goals. The reimbursement rates are determined based on specific criteria. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs reimburses non-Department facilities for care provided to covered veterans at VA, Medicare, or TRICARE payment rates. Covered veterans are those enrolled in the patient enrollment system and have exceeded wait-time goals. Veterans who have waited longer than the Veterans Health Administration's wait-time goals for an appointment, been told no appointments are available within those goals, or live more than 40 miles from a VA medical facility are eligible for reimbursement at non-Department facilities. The Secretary will implement the section on the date of the enactment of the Act, and it does not authorize payment for care not covered under title 38. The Secretary's authority under this section will end for care after 2 years from the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. INDEPENDENT ASSESSMENT OF VETERANS HEALTH ADMINISTRATION PERFORMANCE. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will contract a private sector entity to conduct an independent assessment of hospital care and medical services for veterans, focusing on demographics, care needs, and healthcare resources. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may furnish hospital care and medical services at non-Department facilities through completion of episodes of care, assess access standards, and review organization and tools used for care. The assessment conducted will include the current organization, processes, and tools for clinical staffing and documentation, staffing levels compared to industry standards, IT strategies and weaknesses in clinical documentation technology, and business processes such as non-Department care and revenue collection. The curr_chunk outlines improvement areas qualitatively and quantitatively, provides recommendations for addressing these areas, includes the business case for improvements, and presents findings on how conclusions were established. Additionally, if the Secretary enters into contracts with multiple private sector entities, one entity will be designated as the program integrator. The Secretary designates a program integrator to coordinate assessments conducted by private entities. Reports on independent assessments and VA action plans are submitted to Congress within specified timelines. The assessment findings must include an action plan with a timeline for implementing recommendations. SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON AWARDS AND BONUSES TO EMPLOYEES OF DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is restricted from paying awards or bonuses to employees for fiscal years 2014 through 2016. SEC. 6. OMB ESTIMATE OF BUDGETARY EFFECTS AND NEEDED TRANSFER AUTHORITY. SEC. 6. OMB ESTIMATE OF BUDGETARY EFFECTS AND TRANSFER AUTHORITY: The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must provide budgetary effects estimates for sections 2 and 3, transfer authority for savings from section 5, and request additional resources if needed.
